item.title: Practices for a Missional Church Planting Order
item.description:
Practices for a Missional Church Planting Order

What practices can sustain missional practice and spiritual vitality among church planters?

item.title: Is Missional Good for Us?
item.description:
Is Missional Good for Us?

For those who sense that "being missional" is just another Christian guilt trip.

item.title: CHURCH NOW
item.description:
CHURCH NOW

Stories, articles and videos curated by Christopher B. James on church, culture, and neighborhoods.

item.title: Academia.edu

Academia.edu

Selected Articles on Missional Praxis, Spiritual Formation, and Congregational Studies.

item.title: Public Lecture: New Churches in the None Zone
item.description:
Public Lecture: New Churches in the None Zone

What do church plants in one of the most post-Christian cities in the nation have to teach us? While national headlines herald the decline of Christianity in the United States, scarcely heard are stories from the thousands of new churches and new forms of church that are springing up each year across the country.

item.title: What Churches Can Learn From New Monasticism
item.description:
What Churches Can Learn From New Monasticism

The rise of the “new monasticism” to popular awareness in recent years might lead the uninformed to imagine that Christian communalism is a recent phenomenon. The truth is that Christians have lived in intimate community settings since the very beginnings of the Way. What is new about new monasticism is largely a matter of its historical and geographical contexts, the catchy moniker, and the recent dialog with the Benedictine tradition.

item.title: Is Seattle the Birthplace of a New Religion?
item.description:
Is Seattle the Birthplace of a New Religion?

Kathryn Robinson's latest article in the Seattle Met features my research on New Seattle Churches: "Turns out “post-Christian” Seattle is fertile ground for new church starts."

item.title: The Future Of Religion? A Researcher Looks To Seattle For Clues
item.description:
The Future Of Religion? A Researcher Looks To Seattle For Clues

Marcie Sillman talks with Christopher James of the University of Dubuque about his study of new Seattle churches and what they can tell us about the future of religion.

item.title: Theologians study Seattle for future of 'church'
item.description:
Theologians study Seattle for future of 'church'

The Pacific Northwest is often called the "None Zone" because of the number of people who claim no religious affiliation. Yet, theologians and sociologists are paying close attention to churches in Seattle.
